text: Orange chestnut brown pour with aroma of nuts, banana, spice, and toasted malt. Bready backbone with nuts, banana, and clove. Very nice beer.
Tap at Queen City Brewery, Burlington. Colour is clear orange with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Grain, some sweetness, some caramel and malts. Decent and clear.

This was poured into a pilsener glass.
The appearance was a semi-burnt chestnut brown color with a nice transparency about it. A milky to off white colored foamy one finger head quickly dissipated leaving a small cap in the center of the beer. Light lacing clings yet slides into the beer as it went down.
The smell starts off with some roasty nuttiness along with some bready malts. Light toast slides in for the balance.
The taste had a dry sweetness about it. Id say it gets a bit rough in the aftertaste taking the nuts and bready malts a bit further.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body, surprisingly enough, I dont mind a little more "weight" than what Im used to seeing for the style. Still, a nice sessionability about it yields a smooth carbonation and proving it can be quite smooth.
Overall, Id say Queen City did what theyre supposed to with this one. Id have again preferably with some food.

Draft at the brewery, 7/5/15

Clear amber-brown pour with a tan head. Munich style malt aroma, nice caramel and toffee presences. Lightly hopped. Smooth, clean feel, with a soft carbonation.
Amber in color with a sweet malt smell, sweet malt taste with a little bitterness and no go aroma or taste
On draft at Mt Snow summit lodge. Pours brown with very little head. Sweet malt with notes of brown sugar, toffee and molasses. Not usually my thing but not bad for the style.

En fût. Verre dégustation directement à la brasserie au coût de 1,00$. Arôme: Légère odeur de caramel. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel avec une pointe de céréales grillées. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #6140)

My Bottom Line:
Polished nut-accented malts brush spicy hops before earthy bitterness seals this svelte Dunkel.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam tops the copper shine.
-This is completely süffig, as it should be.
-Malts and hops are both nicely defined and harmonious.
-Caramelized cereals are deep enough to offer more than mild sweetness.

On tap at the brewery.

Purchased howler at brewery. Poured dark brown with light to medium light brown head. Coffee, herb aroma with woody, smoky taste. Light carbonation with a medium finish. A nice dark beer to enjoy in the fall and winter months.

4 oz. taster @ The Brewery. Poured dark brown with a white head. Low carbonation level. Sweet aroma of molasses and roasted malts. The flavor found burnt caramel, roasted malts, and faint hints of barely and smoke. Medium body and a light roasted malt aftertaste. Spot on presentation of the style.

dark brown appearance. Nose is nice, sweetness and cheap candies, butterscotch. Taste is also a sweet candy like taste, some cotton candy, pepsi cola and woody toffee and burnt brown sugar. maybe some mild grape.
